author: @WLBT
title: The gift after life: Body donors honored for contributions to medicine
text:
JACKSON, Miss. (WLBT) - Someone donating their body to science continues to give after their final breath as medical students and researchers learn, treat, and heal. Wednesday, families whose loved ones donated their bodies were honored at the University of Mississippi Medical Center.
A Ceremony of Thanksgiving was held in memory of Anatomical Donors who gave their bodies to UMMC so the next generation of health care professionals could be educated. Medical students thanked the families of donors who are their first patients.
“It kind of brought closure to the decision that he made,” said Alma Dixon.
Her husband, Connie Dixon Sr., died last March at the age of 74. He was a kidney transplant recipient in 2011.
“He decided that he wanted to donate his entire body to the University of Mississippi Medical Center so that future doctors and nurses, and health care professionals would be able to study the body,” said Dixon.
“We learned more from them than we ever will in a classroom,” said Ainsley Sinclair, a first-year Biomedical Sciences grad student. She was among the six students who thanked the families.
Relatives have the option of receiving the donor’s remains or having them buried at the Medical Center Cemetery.
“For us, it’s really important to put a face of a relative to those donors,” said Department of Advanced Biomedical Education Chair Dr. Norma Ojeda.
Students spend countless hours with the donors, learning the body’s anatomy and function.
“We recognize the family members, and we give a little more humanity to that selfless act, and we kind of consider them our big family now,” said Ojeda.
One hundred 20 donors were honored during the ceremony. One hundred 70 medical students are benefiting from the knowledge they gain from the donors.

author: MarketScreener
title: Far Eastern New Century : FENC secures SBTi approval to demonstrate commitment toward Net Zero - MarketScreener
text:
Post Date：2024.07.19 From：FENC In response to global warming and the carbon reduction movement, Far East New Century (FENC) Polyester Business has passed the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) for its greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction pathway. Targets set in line with the Paris Agreement 1.5°C trajectory to mitigate the effects of climate change and cap global temperature, FENC demonstrates a commitment to achieving Net Zero by 2050.
SBTi, launched by the United Nations Global Compact (UNGC), the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), the World Resources Institute (WRI), and the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), provides a scientific framework to enables companies in setting near and long-term GHG reduction goals. Recently, SBTi has become one of the most recognized platforms globally for verifying GHG reduction targets.
Facing escalated climate change, FENC continues to develop green products and deliver eco-friendly and low-carbon emission solutions for our brand partners. By improving energy efficiency, adopting low-emission fuel alternatives, developing renewable energy and fostering raw materials transition, FENC establishes and implements green operations. Through internal carbon pricing mechanisms, we adopt a pragmatic approach through carbon-reduction pathways. FENC actively expands recycling capacity worldwide and converts waste into resources by developing robust recycling technologies. This drive for green innovations in the industries and incorporating green products into our everyday lives.
FENC has set 2030 goals to reduce GHG emissions by 50%, grow green products to 50% and utilize green feedstock to 50%. Our GHG reduction target exceeds SBTi mandate 1.5°C pathway, indicating a strong determination for reducing emissions. FENC seizes the opportunities brought by climate change and received recognition for sustainability endeavors, including the 2023 National Sustainable Development Awards, constituent of MSCI ESG Leaders Indexes, FTSE4Good Emerging Indexes, Taiwan Corporate Governance 100 Index, Sustainalytics' ESG risk rating Top 3% of Commodity Chemicals Industry and TCSA Top 10 Taiwanese Companies Sustainability Model Award.
Approved by SBTi signifies a milestone in FENC sustainability development. We will continue to collaborate with internal and external stakeholders, supply chain associates and customers to implement GHG reduction actions, green operations and achieve Net Zero by 2050.

author: A. Carlino
title: Vento forte e mare agitato: collegamenti marittimi a singhiozzo per Ischia e Procida
text:
Il maltempo sta creando notevoli disagi ai collegamenti marittimi verso le isole di Ischia e Procida. A causa del vento sostenuto e del mare molto mosso, numerose corse degli aliscafi sono state cancellate, mentre altre sono state sospese dalle compagnie di navigazione.
Attualmente, tutti i collegamenti veloci da e per il porto di Forio risultano interrotti, mentre restano regolari le partenze e gli arrivi a Casamicciola. Cancellate invece diverse corse programmate dal Molo Beverello di Napoli verso Marina Grande a Procida e Ischia Porto.
Situazione più stabile per i collegamenti effettuati con navi traghetto, che al momento operano regolarmente sia dal porto di Napoli Porta di Massa che da Pozzuoli . Tuttavia, si teme che ulteriori peggioramenti delle condizioni meteo possano compromettere anche questi servizi nelle prossime ore.
La situazione viene monitorata costantemente dalle autorità portuali e dalle compagnie di navigazione, che invitano i passeggeri a verificare aggiornamenti e variazioni sui programmi di viaggio.
